1.1	DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

Sunoco, LLC is located in Birmingham, Alabama. The facility is an independent wholesale distributor of ethanol and petroleum-based refined products. Operation of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) covered processes involves the use or handling of certain listed regulated substances as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in 40 CFR Part 68. Currently, the regulated substances at the site are hydrogen, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide. 

Hydrogen is stored in a pressurized tank with a maximum rated capacity of 126,360 pounds (lbs). Hydrogen is used as a process catalyst in gasification of oil residues. An administrative control will be placed on the tank restricting it to a 60 percent fill (75,816 lbs).

Anhydrous Ammonia is stored in a pressurized bullet tank with a maximum rated capacity of 2,000 gallons (10,300 lbs). An administrative control will be placed on the tank restricting it to an 80 percent fill (1,600 gallons or 8,240 lbs). 

Sulfur Dioxide is stored in a pressurized bullet tank with a maximum rated capacity of 8,000 gallons (96,000 lbs). An administrative control will be placed on the tank restricting it to a 60 percent fill (4,800 gallons or 55,152 lbs). 

The facility coordinates as measured by the front gate entrance are latitude 33.449350 and longitude -86.877961 decimal degrees; the facility coordinates as measured at the hydrogen tank are latitude 33.451433 and longitude -86.875966; the facility coordinates as measured at the anhydrous ammonia tank are latitude 33.458434 and longitude -86.877097; and the facility coordinates as measured at the sulfur dioxide tank are latitude 33.458434 and longitude -86.877097

1.2	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE PRACTICES AND PROGRAMS 

The facility accidental release prevention and response practices and programs are designed to protect the employees, contractors, visitors, the general public and the environment. Our c

ommitment is demonstrated through the way we conduct daily business to safely maintain and operate the facility and prevent chemical releases. In the event that a release does occur, both mitigation systems and procedures are in place to support and provide the foundation to prevent, control and minimize the impact of the event. In addition to these safety systems and protocols, well trained employees and contractors take active roles in key design, maintenance and operational programs intended to operate the process and prevent releases. In the event of a release, emergency response procedures are in place to minimize any impacts. 

2.0 HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS 

A hazard assessment was performed to analyze releases for potential impacts to the surrounding community and environment. These assessments consist of determining "worst case" and "alternative case" scenarios as specified by the EPA. Since the facility is a Program 3 source, and because of the site lay out, one "worst case" and one "alternative case" scenario have been selected. 


2.3 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

At Sunoco, LLC, numerous plans exist to promote process safety management. Some of these plans include Operation and Maintenance manual, Process Safety Management plan, Fire Safety Analysis plan and the Risk Management Plan. 

3.0 GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

3.1 EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION 

Company employees are encouraged to actively participate in accident prevention at Sunoco, LLC. Employee participation in these efforts is accomplished on several levels both formally and informally. Below are specific procedures and programs implemented at the facility: 
? Quarterly Safety Meetings 
? Behavioral Based Safety (BBS) program 
? Employee Safety Suggestion Program 
? Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) 
? Job Safety Analyses (JSA) 
? Injury and Illness Prevention Plan. 

3.2 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION 

At Sunoco, many written documents are available which provide guidance on how to

safely operate the various processes within the plant. The documents related to process safety information are utilized for training of employees and contractors to identify and understand the hazards associated with each process. The documents are also utilized as a resource when conducting process hazards analyses, and are utilized as a reference during unit operations. 

This documentation consists of information pertaining to: 
? Chemical hazards [i.e. Safety Data Sheets (SDS)] 
? Process technology (drawings, process descriptions, etc.) 
? Equipment in the process. 

Many technical documents, policies and procedures are maintained to provide information to employees concerning the equipment in the process. This information includes, but is not limited to: 

? Process flow diagrams or piping and instrument diagrams (Figure 8, Process Flow Diagrams, Appendix A) 
? Materials of construction 
? Relief systems 
? Safety systems [e.g. emergency shut-off valves (ESVs), etc.] 
? O&M manual 
? Fire safety analysis plan. 

3.3 PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSES 

Sunoco utilizes PHAs (as detailed in Injury & Illness Prevention Plan) to ensure that controls are in place to minimize, manageand control hazards that may potentially affect both on-site and off-site personnel and the environment. By reviewing hazards associated with anticipatable changes in the process, PHAs are designed to assist in identifying operability problems, safety issues and environmental concerns, and the associated causes, consequences, safeguards and risks. In addition to performing PHAs that are triggered by changes, PHAs are also performed to revalidate unit PHAs at least every five years. 

3.4 OPERATING PROCEDURES 

Sunoco has a fully developed set of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the covered processes within the plant. These operating procedures have been developed to be consistent with process safety information, and are maintained as such through annual reviews by operating personnel. 

Oth

er operations procedures also cover safety and health considerations along with specific procedures located at the unit. Written procedures address all aspects listed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the RMP regulations. 

3.5 TRAINING 

Sunoco has a comprehensive training program in place for employees involved in operating the plant. This program is designed to address the needs of new employees and experienced operators. The Injury and Illness Prevention Plan outlines specific training which includes but is not limited to PPE, job specific training, emergency response, chemical hazard information, lock-out/tag-out etc. Sunoco utilizes both classroom and on the job training. Competency testing is done in the form of observation and written testing. All records of training are recorded and maintained at the Plant. 

All PSM/RMP affected employees are properly trained in all areas of handling highly hazardous materials and in the processes that use such materials. This training is further outlined in the Process Safety Management Procedure. 

3.6 CONTRACTORS 

Contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialized work on or adjacent to a covered process must meet certain training and safety performance requirements as described in Sunoco's Process Safety Management Program procedure. Before awarding a contract, the Administrator or designated personnel will screen and evaluate the job skills, methods, safety performance, certifications, and safety programs of any contractors being considered for maintenance, repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or around a process covered under this Program. If a contract company is awarded work by Sunoco, their employees' performance and continued qualification while on site are periodically monitored to ensure that company standards are met on an on-going basis. 

3.7 PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW (PSSR)

As required by OSHA and EPA regulations and in keeping with good operating practice, Sunoco conducts pre-startup safety reviews when a modification to a process is significant enough to change process safety information. As an integral part of our Management of Change (MOC) process and as outlined in the PSM procedure, a PSSR ensures that operability, design parameters, environmental concerns and safety issues are met prior to commissioning the change. It also ensures that all employees and contractors affected by the change are notified and/or trained prior to commissioning the change. Where necessary, field verification occurs to ensure that actual construction meets the design standards specified in the MOC. If the change were determined to be too extensive or complex for a PSSR, a PHA would be performed in addition to a PSSR. 

3.8 MECHANICAL INTEGRITY 

Sunoco has practices and procedures such as the Process Safety Management procedure in place to ensure that equipment has been designed, constructed, installed and maintained to contain the chemicals in the process. Any equipment or system used to store, process and handle highly hazardous chemicals is included in the mechanical integrity program. Also, any other process equipment, safety equipment and backup safety systems used to minimize the impact of a release are included in the program. 

Mechanical components and systems including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, piping components, relief systems, vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, safety equipment, monitoring devices, pumps, etc. are maintained through: 
? Written procedures 
? Training 
? Inspection and testing (when needed) 
? Safely/quickly correcting equipment deficiencies. 

3.9 HOT-WORK 

Sunoco has many safe work practices in place to safely perform job tasks in or near plant process areas. A key practice in preventing unsafe events is the site hot-work program. Hot-work operations on or near a covered process can only begi

n after a Hot-work permit has been issued. Hot-work permits cover welding, cutting, or any other spark or heat producing operations in or near the covered process. Only the site Administrator or their designee can authorize a hot-work permit. The hot-work permit procedure includes a list of hazards that must be identified and details compliance with fire prevention and protection requirements. 


3.10 MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE AUTHORIZATION (MOCA) 

The plant's Process Safety Management procedure describes how the MOCA is implemented at Sunoco, LLC. The procedure provides a system to thoroughly evaluate a process change as it relates to chemicals handled or processed, design or technology, equipment use or maintenance, procedures for operation and changes to ancillary facilities affected by the process. The procedure as practiced assures that the following are addressed prior to a change: 
? Technical basis 
? Actual or potential impact on employee safety and health 
? Effects of temporary changes 
? Operating procedure modifications 
? Employee, contractor notification and training 
? Management authorization/approval requirements. 

Changes (except for "replacement in kind" changes) are evaluated and the complexity is also assessed to determine whether a PSSR is required, or if a more in-depth PHA is appropriate. If a PSSR or a PHA is required, employees are assigned task(s) to: 
? Update process information or maintenance schedules or procedures 
? Provide employee and/or contractor training 
? Revise operating procedures 
? Compose and implement new safety procedures as appropriate, etc. 

3.11 INCIDENT INVESTIGATION 

A written incident investigation and reporting guideline (Process Safety Management) has been developed and implemented by plant management. This guideline formalizes the process by which an accident must be reported and can be investigated by employees (and contractors when appropriate) to determine the direct and/or contributing causes of an incident

. Both types of causes are used to help formulate corrective action(s) intended to prevent the possibility of a reoccurrence of the specific accident or a similar event. Draft reports of the incident are prepared for the Management Team Investigation (MTI). 

3.12 EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE 

The plant's programs and capabilities for emergency planning and response are discussed in detail in a later section of this plan. 

3.13 COMPLIANCE AUDITS 

It is the company's policy to conduct an audit at least every three years on the elements of OSHA's PSM standard and EPA's RMP regulation. This will assure that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and are being followed. Various employees including hourly and salaried employees participate in the audit by gathering required documentation, researching requested documentation, verifying information and participating in interviews. 

4.0 CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 

The Accident Prevention Programs described above ensure the safe operations and management of the chemical hazards. In addition to these programs and procedures, there are safety systems and equipment installed in the plant to provide various levels of safety. The levels of safety include: 
1) Prevention 
2) Quick detection 
3) Containment/control 
4) Mitigation. 


5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

5.1 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN 

The plant has a comprehensive set of emergency procedures consisting of several plans which have been written to address the various types of anticipatable emergencies that might occur at the plant: 

? Emergency Response Procedures
? Emergency Action Plan (EAP) 
? Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan 
? Process Safety Management 
? Fire Safety Analysis Plan (FSA) 
? O&M Manual (Hydrogen 9,000 gallon Bulk Storage Tank System)  
Customer Manual (Anhydrous Ammonia Bulk Storage Tank System) 
? O&M Manual (Sulfur Dioxide Bulk Storage Tank System) 

Since coordination occurs between the site and lo

cal fire department for emergencies on the hydrogen, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide covered processes, the remaining sections of §68.95 Emergency Response do not apply at this time, given that Sunoco, LLC employees will only respond to routine small release events during the course of normal operation and would not be the primary responder during a catastrophic event on any of the RMP regulated processes. 

6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Future plans to improve safety are developed through several venues including the Employee Safety Suggestion program, Quarterly Safety Meetings, Process Hazard Analyses, Job Safety Analysis, and the BBS program. These safety action items are implemented through individual employees, employee committees or teams, and are supported by the site management team.
